other classifies a piece of text using its first n words and the n next words after that. It can process text containing punctuations or special characters. It is based on a Bayes Network Model, where each word has a probability of occurring in a given class along with its neighbors in the dictionary.

## Syntax

```
classify(Text, "classification") where
```

## Returns

A list of classifications (e.g., course, department) for the text `Text`. If the text can not be classified in any of its elements, it is assumed to be an error and a list with only a single classification `"other" ` will be returned:

```
[["course", "571 Main Page", "computer-science"], ["department", "Colgate University Department of Computer Science"]]

##### The format of a classification example.txt file
`[Title]` and `Body` are the only two fields that must be present for each line in the classification text file. For the other fields (see "Link" below) they can be absent or empty, but if your project includes classification of any of these then you will need to include them as well. 
- [Title] The title is a string of text in quotes that should accurately describe this example. 
- [Body] The body contains the actual example, and consists of two parts:

import os
from urllib.parse import unquote_plus

class FileUtils(object):
    def __init__(self, folderpath=''):
        self._folderpath = folderpath

    def get_filepath_for(self, filename):
        filepath = os.path.join(
            self._folderpath, unquote_plus(filename))

        return filepath

### POSIX-format

This format is the simplest to generate and parse, however it lacks support for links or any other formatting information that is needed to make a well structured site list easier to use. However, the `class`es should be used in the `link` tags when possible so that they can be automatically parsed by the program.

```
Title: Text that will appear as the page title
Body: Any text or HTML to be included on the page before the class link list
Link: List of links formatted using a specific format (see below).
